description: Confederation vs confederation head-to-head records at FIFA World Cup finals (1930-2022). Data sourced from RSSSF (Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation), FIFA.com, and Wikipedia.
dataCoverage: FIFA World Cup finals 1930-2022 (22 tournaments, 964 matches total)

CONCACAF.fullName: Confederation of North, Central America and Caribbean Association Football

OFC.note: Australia moved from OFC to AFC in 2006

headToHead.summary: The most iconic rivalry in World Cup history. Europe holds a slight edge overall, but South America has dominated in World Cup finals (10 titles vs 12). This is the only inter-confederation pairing to have produced World Cup champions.
notableResults: 2006 Final: Italy 1-1 France (Italy won 5-3 on penalties)
2022 Final: Argentina 3-3 France (Argentina won 4-2 on penalties)

headToHead.summary: Europe has historically dominated this matchup, but African teams have produced memorable upsets. Morocco's 2022 semi-final run marked a turning point, beating Belgium, Spain, and Portugal.
notableResults: 1982: Algeria 2-1 West Germany (first African win vs European side at WC)
2022: Morocco 2-0 Belgium, Morocco 0-0 Spain (Morocco won 3-0 pens)

headToHead.summary: Europe has the strongest advantage in this pairing, with Asian teams winning fewer than 1 in 6 matches. However, the 2022 World Cup saw a surge in Asian upsets against European teams.
notableResults: 2002: South Korea 2-1 Spain (QF, South Korea reached SF as co-hosts)
2018: South Korea 2-0 Germany (defending champions eliminated in group)

headToHead.summary: Europe dominates this matchup heavily. Mexico accounts for the majority of CONCACAF's wins, while the USA's progress has been mainly against non-European opponents. CONCACAF teams tend to grind out draws rather than wins.
notableResults: 1950: USA 1-0 England (one of the biggest upsets in WC history)
1970: Mexico 1-0 Belgium (Mexico reached QF as hosts)
2014: Costa Rica 0-0 England, topped group with Italy and Uruguay

headToHead.summary: South America dominates this matchup with nearly a 68% win rate. African teams have rarely beaten South American opponents at the World Cup, though Cameroon's famous 1990 victory over Argentina remains a landmark moment.
notableResults: 1990: Cameroon 1-0 Argentina (opening match, defending champions beaten)
2010: Ghana 1-1 Uruguay (QF, Suarez handball, Ghana lost on pens)
2022: Cameroon 1-0 Brazil (group stage, but Brazil already qualified)

headToHead.summary: South America's most lopsided matchup. Asian teams have only beaten South American opponents twice in World Cup history, with a goal ratio of nearly 4:1 in CONMEBOL's favor.
notableResults: 1978: Iran 1-1 Peru (first Asian point vs South America in WC)
2018: Colombia 1-2 Japan (group stage, Colombia red card early)
2022: Saudi Arabia 2-1 Argentina (historic upset, ended 36-game unbeaten run)

headToHead.summary: South America's second most dominant matchup. CONCACAF teams have won only 4 of 29 matches against South American opponents, with Mexico accounting for most of those results.
notableResults: 1994: USA 2-1 Colombia (group stage, Escobar own goal)
2014: Costa Rica topped Group D ahead of Uruguay, Italy, England

headToHead.summary: The most evenly matched inter-confederation pairing. Africa holds a slight edge in wins but Asia has scored more goals. A remarkably balanced rivalry with a very high draw rate.
notableResults: 2022: South Korea 2-3 Ghana (entertaining group stage match)

headToHead.summary: A relatively rare World Cup matchup with only 10 meetings. Africa holds the edge, but the sample size is small. Ghana's 2010 victory over the USA in the Round of 16 is the most significant result.

A closely contested pairing with Asian teams holding a slight edge. Limited sample size as these teams rarely meet in World Cup group stages. Both confederations have been expanding their competitiveness.
notableResults: 2002: South Korea 1-0 USA (group stage, co-host South Korea)

keyInsights: UEFA (Europe) and CONMEBOL (South America) are the only confederations to have produced World Cup winners, combining for all 22 titles (12 and 10 respectively).
CONMEBOL has the highest inter-confederation win rate, dominating AFC (73.3%), CONCACAF (75.9%), and CAF (67.7%) matchups.
UEFA has the most total World Cup matches played (1,080) and wins (468) of any confederation.
CAF vs AFC is the most balanced inter-confederation pairing with a near-equal record and high draw rate (35%).

The 2022 Qatar World Cup was a breakout tournament for both AFC and CAF teams, with Saudi Arabia beating Argentina, Japan beating Germany and Spain, Morocco reaching the semi-finals, and Australia advancing to the Round of 16.
African nations have never won the World Cup, but Morocco's 2022 semi-final run was the closest any non-UEFA/CONMEBOL team has come to the final.
South Korea's 4th place finish in 2002 remains the best result by an AFC member at a World Cup.
